modules.title: Module 1: HTML Fundamentals
modules.description: Start with the absolute basics of HTML and web structure.

lessons.title: Introduction to HTML
lessons.theory: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the standard markup language for documents designed to be displayed in a web browser. It defines the structure of web content using markup. HTML elements are the building blocks of HTML pages.
lessons.code:
My First Heading

My first paragraph.

quiz.question: What does HTML stand for?

lessons.title: HTML Editors
lessons.theory: Web pages can be created and modified by using professional HTML editors. However, for learning HTML we recommend a simple text editor like Notepad (PC) or TextEdit (Mac).
lessons.code: Hello World

quiz.question: Which extension is used to save an HTML file?

lessons.title: HTML Basic Examples
lessons.theory: All HTML documents must start with a document type declaration: <!DOCTYPE html>. The HTML document itself begins with <html> and ends with </html>. The visible part of the HTML document is between <body> and </body>.
lessons.code:
My First Heading

My first paragraph.

quiz.question: Where is the visible content of a webpage placed?

lessons.title: HTML Elements
lessons.theory: An HTML element is defined by a start tag, some content, and an end tag. Examples: <h1>, <p>, <br>. Some elements are empty (like <br>) and do not have an end tag.
lessons.code:
This is a Heading

This is a paragraph.

quiz.question: Which element is an empty element (has no closing tag)?

lessons.title: HTML Attributes
lessons.theory: Attributes provide additional information about HTML elements. All HTML elements can have attributes. Attributes are always specified in the start tag. They usually come in name/value pairs like: name="value".
lessons.code: Visit Google

quiz.question: Which attribute specifies the URL for a link?

project.title: My First Webpage
project.description: Create a simple webpage with a heading, a paragraph, and a link to your favorite website.

modules.title: Module 2: Text & Formatting
modules.description: Learn how to format text, use headings, and paragraphs.

lessons.title: HTML Headings
lessons.theory: HTML headings are defined with the <h1> to <h6> tags. <h1> defines the most important heading. <h6> defines the least important heading.
lessons.code:
Heading 1

Heading 2

Heading 3

Heading 4

Heading 5
Heading 6

quiz.question: Which HTML tag defines the most important heading?

lessons.title: HTML Paragraphs
lessons.theory: The HTML <p> element defines a paragraph. A paragraph always starts on a new line, and browsers automatically add some white space (a margin) before and after a paragraph.
lessons.code:
This is a paragraph.

This is another paragraph.

quiz.question: Which tag defines a paragraph?

lessons.title: HTML Styles
lessons.theory: The HTML style attribute is used to add styles to an element, such as color, font, size, and more.
lessons.code:
I am red

I am blue

I am big

quiz.question: Which attribute is used to add inline styles?

lessons.title: HTML Formatting
lessons.theory: HTML contains several elements for defining text with a special meaning. Examples: <b> (bold), <i> (italic), <strong> (important), <em> (emphasized), <mark> (marked), <small> (smaller), <del> (deleted), <ins> (inserted), <sub> (subscript), <sup> (superscript).
lessons.code:
Bold text

Italic text

This is subscript and superscript

quiz.question: Which tag makes text bold?

lessons.title: HTML Quotations
lessons.theory: The HTML <blockquote> element defines a section that is quoted from another source. The HTML <q> tag defines a short quotation.
lessons.code:
Browsers usually indent blockquote elements.

For 50 years, WWF has been protecting the future of nature.

quiz.question: Which tag is used for long quotations?

lessons.title: HTML Comments
lessons.theory: HTML comments are not displayed in the browser, but they can help document your HTML source code. You can add comments to your HTML source by using the following syntax: <!-- Write your comments here -->.
lessons.code: This is a paragraph.

quiz.question: How do you insert a comment in HTML?

project.title: Formatted Blog Post
project.description: Create a blog post layout using headings, paragraphs, bold text, italics, and a blockquote.

modules.title: Module 3: Links, Images & Media
modules.description: Connecting pages and adding visual content.

lessons.title: HTML Links
lessons.theory: HTML links are defined with the <a> tag. The destination address is specified in the href attribute. Links allow users to click their way from page to page.
lessons.code: Visit W3Schools.com!

quiz.question: Which attribute specifies the link destination?

lessons.title: HTML Images
lessons.theory: HTML images are defined with the <img> tag. The source file (src), alternative text (alt), width, and height are provided as attributes.

quiz.question: Which attribute specifies the path to the image?

lessons.title: HTML Favicon
lessons.theory: A favicon is a small image displayed next to the page title in the browser tab.
lessons.code: <link rel="icon" type="image/x-icon" href="https://www.w3schools.com/favicon.ico">

quiz.question: Where is the favicon link placed?

lessons.title: HTML Multimedia
lessons.theory: Multimedia comes in many different formats. It can be almost anything you can hear or see, like images, music, sound, videos, records, films, animations, and more.
lessons.code: <!-- No code example for general concept -->

quiz.question: Which of these is NOT a multimedia format?

lessons.title: HTML Video
lessons.theory: The HTML <video> element specifies a standard way to embed a video in a web page.
lessons.code:
<video width="320" height="240" controls>
  <source src="https://www.w3schools.com/html/mov_bbb.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>

quiz.question: Which attribute adds play/pause controls to the video?

lessons.title: HTML Audio
lessons.theory: The HTML <audio> element is used to play an audio file on a web page.
lessons.code:
<audio controls>
  <source src="https://www.w3schools.com/html/horse.ogg" type="audio/ogg">
  <source src="https://www.w3schools.com/html/horse.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
  Your browser does not support the audio element.
</audio>

quiz.question: Which tag is used to embed audio?

lessons.title: HTML YouTube
lessons.theory: The easiest way to play videos in HTML is to use YouTube. You can use an <iframe> to display the video.
lessons.code:
<iframe width="420" height="315"
src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/tgbNymZ7vqY">
</iframe>

quiz.question: Which tag is commonly used to embed YouTube videos?

project.title: Multimedia Page
project.description: Create a page with an image, a link to another site, and an embedded YouTube video.

lessons.title: HTML Tables
lessons.theory: HTML tables allow web developers to arrange data into rows and columns. Defined with <table>, <tr>, <th>, and <td>.
lessons.code:
Firstname Lastname
Peter Griffin

quiz.question: Which tag defines a table row?

lessons.title: HTML Lists
lessons.theory: HTML lists allow web developers to group a set of related items in lists. Unordered lists use <ul>, ordered lists use <ol>, and list items use <li>.
lessons.code:
• Coffee
  • Tea
  1. First
  2. Second

quiz.question: Which tag is used for an ordered list?

lessons.title: Block & Inline
lessons.theory: Every HTML element has a default display value. Block-level elements start on a new line (e.g., <div>, <p>). Inline elements do not (e.g., <span>, <a>).
lessons.code:
This is a block element
This is an inline element

quiz.question: Which of these is a block-level element?

lessons.title: HTML Classes
lessons.theory: The class attribute is used to specify a class for an HTML element. Multiple HTML elements can share the same class. Used by CSS and JavaScript to select elements.
lessons.code:
London

London is the capital of England.

quiz.question: Can multiple elements have the same class?

lessons.title: HTML Id
lessons.theory: The id attribute is used to specify a unique id for an HTML element. You cannot have more than one element with the same id in an HTML document.
lessons.code: My Header

quiz.question: Can multiple elements have the same id?

lessons.title: HTML Iframes
lessons.theory: An HTML iframe is used to display a web page within a web page.
lessons.code: <iframe src="https://www.w3schools.com" title="W3Schools Free Online Web Tutorials"></iframe>

quiz.question: What is an iframe used for?
options: To display a web page within a web page
To create a frame for an image

project.title: Data Dashboard
project.description: Create a page with a table of data and a list of key points.

lessons.title: HTML Forms
lessons.theory: An HTML form is used to collect user input. The user input is most often sent to a server for processing.

quiz.question: Which element is used to create a form?

lessons.title: Form Attributes
lessons.theory: The <form> element has attributes like action (where to send data), target (where to open response), and method (GET or POST).
lessons.code:
<form action="/action_page.php" method="get" target="_blank">
  <!-- form elements -->
</form>

quiz.question: Which attribute specifies the HTTP method to be used?

lessons.title: Form Elements
lessons.theory: The <form> element can contain various types of input elements: <input>, <label>, <select>, <textarea>, <button>, <fieldset>, <legend>, <datalist>, <output>, <option>, <optgroup>.
lessons.code:
<label for="cars">Choose a car:</label>
<select id="cars" name="cars">
  <option value="volvo">Volvo</option>
  <option value="saab">Saab</option>
</select>

quiz.question: Which element creates a drop-down list?

lessons.title: Input Types
lessons.theory: The <input> element is the most used form element. It can be displayed in many ways, depending on the type attribute: text, password, submit, radio, checkbox, button, color, date, email, number, range, etc.
lessons.code:
<input type="button" onclick="alert('Hello World!')" value="Click Me!">
<input type="checkbox" id="vehicle1" name="vehicle1" value="Bike">
<input type="color" id="favcolor" name="favcolor" value="#ff0000">

quiz.question: Which input type is used for passwords?

lessons.title: Input Attributes
lessons.theory: The <input> element has many attributes: value, readonly, disabled, size, maxlength, min, max, multiple, pattern, placeholder, required, step, autofocus, etc.
lessons.code:
<input type="text" name="fname" value="John" readonly>
<input type="text" name="lname" placeholder="Last Name" required>

quiz.question: Which attribute specifies that an input field must be filled out?

project.title: Registration Form
project.description: Build a user registration form with text inputs, radio buttons, a checkbox, and a submit button.

lessons.title: HTML Semantics
lessons.theory: Semantic elements clearly describe their meaning to both the browser and the developer. Examples: <form>, <table>, and <article> - Clearly defines its content. Non-semantic: <div> and <span> - Tells nothing about its content.
lessons.code:
Google Chrome

Google Chrome is a web browser developed by Google.

quiz.question: Which of these is a semantic element?

lessons.title: HTML Style Guide
lessons.theory: Consistent coding style is important. Always declare document type, use lowercase element names, close all HTML elements, use lowercase attribute names, always quote attribute values.
lessons.code: This is a paragraph.

quiz.question: Should HTML tags be uppercase or lowercase in HTML5?
options: It doesn't matter, but lowercase is recommended

lessons.title: HTML Entities
lessons.theory: Reserved characters in HTML must be replaced with character entities. Characters not present on your keyboard can also be replaced by entities.
lessons.code:
I will display <

I will display <

quiz.question: What is the entity for the less than (<) sign?

lessons.title: HTML Symbols
lessons.theory: Many mathematical, technical, and currency symbols are not present on a normal keyboard. To add these to an HTML page, you can use the entity name or the entity number.
lessons.code:
I will display €

I will display €

quiz.question: Which entity displays the Euro sign?

lessons.title: HTML Emojis
lessons.theory: Emojis are characters from the UTF-8 character set. To display an emoji, you can use the decimal or hexadecimal reference.

quiz.question: Are emojis images?

project.title: Semantic Blog Layout
project.description: Refactor your blog post to use semantic tags like <header>, <nav>, <section>, <article>, and <footer>.

lessons.title: HTML Canvas
lessons.theory: The HTML <canvas> element is used to draw graphics, on the fly, via scripting (usually JavaScript). The <canvas> element is only a container for graphics. You must use a script to actually draw the graphics.
lessons.code:
<canvas id="myCanvas" width="200" height="100" style="border:1px solid #000000;"></canvas>
<script>
var c = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
var ctx = c.getContext("2d");
ctx.moveTo(0, 0);
ctx.lineTo(200, 100);
ctx.stroke();
</script>

quiz.question: What is used to draw on the canvas?

lessons.title: HTML SVG
lessons.theory: SVG defines vector-based graphics in XML format. SVG stands for Scalable Vector Graphics.
lessons.code:
<svg width="100" height="100">
  <circle cx="50" cy="50" r="40" stroke="green" stroke-width="4" fill="yellow" />
</svg>

quiz.question: What does SVG stand for?

lessons.title: HTML Geolocation
lessons.theory: The HTML Geolocation API is used to locate a user's position. Since this can compromise privacy, the position is not available unless the user approves it.

quiz.question: Does the user need to approve geolocation access?

lessons.title: HTML Drag/Drop
lessons.theory: In HTML, any element can be dragged and dropped.

quiz.question: Which attribute makes an element draggable?

lessons.title: HTML Web Storage
lessons.theory: With web storage, web applications can store data locally within the user's browser. Before HTML5, application data had to be stored in cookies, included in every server request. Web storage is more secure, and large amounts of data can be stored locally, without affecting website performance.
lessons.code:
<script>
// Store
localStorage.setItem("lastname", "Smith");
// Retrieve
document.getElementById("result").innerHTML = localStorage.getItem("lastname");
</script>

quiz.question: Which object stores data with no expiration date?

lessons.title: HTML Web Workers
lessons.theory: A web worker is a JavaScript that runs in the background, independently of other scripts, without affecting the performance of the page. You can continue to do whatever you want: clicking, selecting things, etc., while the web worker runs in the background.
lessons.code: Web Workers run in background.

quiz.question: Do Web Workers affect page performance?

project.title: Interactive Map
project.description: Use Geolocation API to get coordinates and display them (or integrate with a map service).
